context:
Spectre attacks have upended the foundations of computer
security [1]—showing that attackers can violate
security boundaries and steal secrets despite countermeasures such as
process isolation [2],
software fault isolation (SFI) [3],
and control flow integrity (CFI) [4].
In response, the security community has been working on program analysis tools
to both find Spectre vulnerabilities and to guide mitigations (e.g., compiler
passes) that make real programs secure in the presence of this class of
attacks.
However, because Spectre attacks—and speculative execution in
general—violate our typical assumptions and abstractions, they have proven
particularly challenging to reason about and to defend against.

[1].ref: Paul Kocher, Jann Horn, Anders Fogh, Daniel Genkin, Daniel Gruss, Werner Haas, Mike Hamburg, Moritz Lipp, Stefan Mangard, Thomas Prescher, Michael Schwarz, and Yuval Yarom. 2019. Spectre Attacks: Exploiting Speculative Execution. In IEEE S&P.

[2].ref: Yongzheng Wu, Sai Sathyanarayan, Roland HC Yap, and Zhenkai Liang. 2012. Codejail: Application-transparent isolation of libraries with tight program interactions. In European Symposium on Research in Computer Security.

[3].ref: Robert Wahbe, Steven Lucco, Thomas E. Anderson, and Susan L. Graham. 1993. Efficient Software-Based Fault Isolation. In SOSP.

[4].ref: Martín Abadi, Mihai Budiu, Úlfar Erlingsson, and Jay Ligatti. 2009. Control-Flow Integrity Principles, Implementations, and Applications. TISSEC (2009).
